lines.text: Enter the COUNTESS and her Porter

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: Porter, remember what I gave in charge; And when you have done so, bring the keys to me.

lines.speaker: porter
lines.text: Madam, I will. COUNTESS
Exit

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: The plot is laid: if all things fall out right, I shall as famous be by this exploit As Scythian Tomyris by Cyrus' death. Great is the rumor of this dreadful knight, And his achievements of no less account: Fain would mine eyes be witness with mine ears, To give their censure of these rare reports.
Enter Messenger and TALBOT

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Madam, According as your ladyship desired, By message craved, so is Lord Talbot come. COUNTESS

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: And he is welcome. What! is this the man?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Madam, it is. COUNTESS

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: Is this the scourge of France? Is this the Talbot, so much fear'd abroad That with his name the mothers still their babes? I see report is fabulous and false: I thought I should have seen some Hercules, A second Hector, for his grim aspect, And large proportion of his strong-knit limbs. Alas, this is a child, a silly dwarf! It cannot be this weak and writhled shrimp Should strike such terror to his enemies.

lines.speaker: talbot
lines.text: Madam, I have been bold to trouble you; But since your ladyship is not at leisure, I'll sort some other time to visit you. COUNTESS

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: What means he now? Go ask him whither he goes.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Stay, my Lord Talbot; for my lady craves To know the cause of your abrupt departure.

lines.speaker: talbot
lines.text: Marry, for that she's in a wrong belief, I go to certify her Talbot's here. COUNTESS
Re-enter Porter with keys

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: If thou be he, then art thou prisoner.

lines.speaker: talbot
lines.text: Prisoner! to whom? COUNTESS

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: To me, blood-thirsty lord; And for that cause I trained thee to my house. Long time thy shadow hath been thrall to me, For in my gallery thy picture hangs: But now the substance shall endure the like, And I will chain these legs and arms of thine, That hast by tyranny these many years Wasted our country, slain our citizens And sent our sons and husbands captivate.

lines.speaker: talbot
lines.text: Ha, ha, ha! COUNTESS

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: Laughest thou, wretch? thy mirth shall turn to moan.

lines.speaker: talbot
lines.text: I laugh to see your ladyship so fond To think that you have aught but Talbot's shadow Whereon to practise your severity. COUNTESS

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: Why, art not thou the man?

lines.speaker: talbot
lines.text: I am indeed. COUNTESS

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: Then have I substance too.

lines.speaker: talbot
lines.text: No, no, I am but shadow of myself: You are deceived, my substance is not here; For what you see is but the smallest part And least proportion of humanity: I tell you, madam, were the whole frame here, It is of such a spacious lofty pitch, Your roof were not sufficient to contain't. COUNTESS

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: This is a riddling merchant for the nonce; He will be here, and yet he is not here: How can these contrarieties agree?

lines.speaker: talbot
lines.text: That will I show you presently. Winds his horn. Drums strike up: a peal of ordnance. Enter soldiers How say you, madam? are you now persuaded That Talbot is but shadow of himself? These are his substance, sinews, arms and strength, With which he yoketh your rebellious necks, Razeth your cities and subverts your towns And in a moment makes them desolate. COUNTESS

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: Victorious Talbot! pardon my abuse: I find thou art no less than fame hath bruited And more than may be gather'd by thy shape. Let my presumption not provoke thy wrath; For I am sorry that with reverence I did not entertain thee as thou art.

lines.speaker: talbot
lines.text: Be not dismay'd, fair lady; nor misconstrue The mind of Talbot, as you did mistake The outward composition of his body. What you have done hath not offended me; Nor other satisfaction do I crave, But only, with your patience, that we may Taste of your wine and see what cates you have; For soldiers' stomachs always serve them well. COUNTESS

lines.speaker: of auvergne
lines.text: With all my heart, and think me honoured To feast so great a warrior in my house. RICHARD
Exeunt
